facts.text: On the morning of March 13, 1962, Abdul Sheikh in the company of his son Adut, aged 13, went to his field in village Noapara to uproot linseed plants.
Two appellants, Afrahim and Jesed, appeared; Afrahim asked Jesed to catch Abdul Sheikh, who took to his heels and was chased, overtaken, and thrown down on the ground.

Remaining appellants appeared: Jarahim armed with ballam hit Abdul on legs; Manu with sabal (crowbar) struck him; Mesher with lathi struck him; Makid held legs; Afrahim and Jesed held head and shoulders.
Incident witnessed by Adut and two others; Assistant Sessions Judge relied on their testimony to conclude offence committed as described.
Abdul Sheikh seriously injured: both legs below knee fractured, one arm above wrist fractured, incised wounds, bruises.
Examined by Dr. Bashiruddin who gave first aid; Abdul named all six appellants; later removed to Nalhati Health Centre, succumbed to injuries before dying declaration recorded.
Abdul made dying declarations to prosecution witnesses naming six appellants as assailants.
Proof of enmity between appellants and Abdul Sheikh; two parties involved.
Six appellants convicted by Assistant Sessions Judge, Birbhum under s.304 Part II r/w s.34 IPC, sentenced to six years RI each.
Appeal to Calcutta High Court summarily dismissed on March 5, 1963.
High Court rejected certificate for appeal to Supreme Court, citing Full Bench in Ibra Akanda v. Emperor.

legal_issues.text: Whether s.34 IPC can be read in conjunction with Part II of s.304 IPC.

petitioner_arguments.text: Conviction under s.304 Part II illegal because s.34 cannot be called in aid as Part II concerns knowledge and excludes intention.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Minority view of Das J. in Ibra Akanda v. Emperor; Ramnath v. Emperor (Allahabad); Sahibzada v. The Crown (Peshawar); Debi Charan Haldar v. Emperor (Calcutta doubts on s.34 with s.304 Part I)

respondent_arguments.text: S.34 can be read with Part II of s.304; facts show act in furtherance of common intention with prior concert.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Full Bench Allahabad in Saidu Khan v. State; majority in Ibra Akanda v. Emperor

court_reasoning.text: Assumed facts as per prosecution witnesses; facts establish prior concert and common intention to beat Abdul Sheikh; six accused could not have appeared simultaneously without prior concert.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Facts prove common intention satisfied; chased, overthrown, held down, beaten.

court_reasoning.text: S.34 applies to criminal act (series of acts) done in furtherance of common intention; each liable as if done alone; applies to totality resulting in culpable homicide not amounting to murder.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Common intention to beat; knowledge each blow likely to cause death satisfies Part II s.304 with s.34.

court_reasoning.text: Explains ss.33,34,35,37,38 IPC; s.34/35 for shared intention/knowledge; s.37 cooperation; s.38 varying responsibility.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Part II s.304 not divorced from intention; common intention for beating act, shared knowledge of likely death.

court_reasoning.text: Agrees with majority in Ibra Akanda (Lodge J., Khundkar J.) and Allahabad Full Bench Saidu Khan; distinguishes minority views.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Prior concert in group attack fulfills s.34 even for Part II.

holdings.text: S.34 IPC can be read with Part II of s.304 IPC where common intention for criminal act (beating) and shared knowledge that it is likely to cause death.

precedents_cited.relevance: Full Bench majority (Lodge J., Khundkar J.) held s.34 can be read with Part II s.304; minority (Das J.) dissented
Single Judge Allahabad supported view s.34 inapplicable to Part II s.304
Division Bench Peshawar supported view s.34 inapplicable
Calcutta Division Bench expressed doubts on s.34 with Part I s.304
Allahabad Full Bench held s.34 can be read with Part II s.304
Privy Council: s.34 deals with separate acts in furtherance of common intention; each liable for result

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: S.34 with Part II s.304 applies to shared common intention for beating with knowledge likely to cause death; defines culpable homicide not amounting to murder

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; conviction under s.304 Part II r/w s.34 IPC and sentences upheld as proper; no interference warranted.

key_quotes.text: "When a criminal act is done by several persons, in furtherance of the common intention of all, each of such persons is liable for that act in the same manner as if it were done by him alone."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes s.34 IPC central to holding

key_quotes.text: "Sec. 34 I.P.C. deals with the doing of separate acts, similar or diverse, by several persons if all are done in furtherance of a common intention, each person is liable for the result of them all as if he had done them himself."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Cites Barendra Kumar Ghosh on scope of s.34

key_quotes.text: "The common intention was to beat Abdul Sheikh, and that common intention was, as we have held above, shared by all of them."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key finding on prior concert and applicability to facts
